newsitem.title: CHINA: China stocks ignore stamp duty hike, rise solidly.
newsitem.headline: China stocks ignore stamp duty hike, rise solidly.

text.p: China's shares leapt up again on Monday, ignoring a hike in the stock trading stamp tax, and brokers said the government was unlikely to introduce serious market cooling measures ahead of the Hong Kong handover.
The Shanghai B index rose 1.663 points or 1.77 percent to 95.794 points, but was off an intraday high of 97.865 points on profit-taking due to market uncertainties, brokers said.
Volume was 32.437 million shares worth $22.180 million.

The strong A share performance was the main factor behind the B share gains, but the continuing surge in the A share markets is increasing concerns about a possible government clampdown, brokers said.
"Recent A share movements are abnormal," said one broker. "Beijing will not tolerate the over-speculative market."
The Shanghai A index rose 34.884 points or 2.27 percent to 1,568.999 points.
"The B index will move between 93 to 98 points in the next few days if there is no major negative news in sight," another broker said.
Inner Mongolia Erdos Cashmere Products was the star on institutional buying to support its new 100 million share issue, surging $0.102 or 9.98 percent to $1.124 on volume of 706,200 shares.

Shanghai Refrigerator Compressor was the most actively traded and become the second-biggest winner on heavy institutional buying, soaring $0.082 or 9.95 percent to $0.906 on volume of 2.5 million shares.
The Shenzhen B share index put on 3.88 points or 2.16 percent to 183.50 on turnover of HK$184.3 million with the A index hitting an historic high of 546.02, up 20.88 points or 3.98 percent.

"People believe Beijing is unlikely to announce market crackdown measures in the short term to avoid a stock market crash around the Hong Kong handover on July 1," an analyst at China Southern Securities said.
Beijing on Friday announced a rise in the stock trading stamp tax to 0.5 percent from 0.3 percent, but the markets did not even blink at the news on Monday.

"The A share market rose because the stamp tax hike has been the government's only measure recently to cool the market," an analyst at Shenzhen J&A Securities said. "People really do not care about it given the bullishness of the market."
The B shares are likely to extend gains into Tuesday if the A share market continues to surge, analysts said. But they cautioned about the possibility of heavy profit-taking.
On the B share market, Jiangling Motors Corp was the best performer, up HK$0.39 or 9.95 percent to HK$4.31.
On the Shenzhen A share market, hot money was diverted into cheap and medium-priced shares which have performed less strongly than the blue chips, brokers said.
